syllabus:
**English III: Literature and Culture in English (General)**

**Prof. Aaron Deveson**

Email: aaron.c.deveson@gmail.com

**\*\*\*\*Course taught entirely in English\*\*\*\***

**Aims and methods**

The purpose of this course is to improve students’ knowledge and appreciation of literary and spoken English. The course focuses on two novels, _Sense and Sensibility_ (1811) by Jane Austen and _Brooklyn_ (2009) by the Irish author Colm Tóibín.  

The themes that bind this course together include the following: social class, nationality, sexuality, friendship, and ethical choices.

**Texts**

Students will need to acquire the Oxford Bookworms (adapted text) version of _Sense and Sensibility_ and the Penguin edition of _Brooklyn_.

**Typical lesson structure**     

Student presentations (see Grading)

Teacher’s lecture and class discussion of literary text; close reading

Viewing of film/TV adaptations of text(s)

**Grading**

**Presentation (20%).** Each student will give one presentation, which should last no longer than 4 mins. The presentation will provide a summary, interpretative analysis and vocabulary guide for a section of a novel. The presentation must include at least three images.

**Midterm and final (40% each).** The midterm and final exams will be split into two sections. The first section (50%) requires students to explain the contextual meaning of a short passage from the relevant novel. In the second section (50%), students have to write a medium-length essay showing their understanding and offering their interpretations of the relevant novel.

Plagiarism will not be tolerated: document every source you make use of in your work.

 **Schedule** (may be slightly changed to fit in with Taiwanese holidays)

_Sense and Sensibility_

1.  Intro/Historical background

2.  Chapters 1 and 2

3.  Chapters 3 and 4

4.  Chapters 5 and 6

5.  Chapters 7 and 8

6.  Chapters 9 and 10

7.  Synthesis

8.  Midterm

_Brooklyn_

9_._   Historical background

10_._ Part One

11\. Part Two

12\. Part Three

13\. Part Three contd.

14\. Part Three contd.

15\. Part Four

16\. Synthesis

17\. Final

 **And just to remind you all: this course is taught entirely in English!**
